title: 103_hr2535
content: AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE PRIORITY HEALTH CARE TO VETERANS OF THE PERSIAN GULF WAR. Inpatient Care amendment to provide hospital care and nursing home care for veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War. Amendment to provide hospital and nursing home care for veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War, regardless of insufficient medical evidence linking the disability to the exposure. Amendments include expanding eligibility criteria and specifying outpatient care provisions. Amendment expands eligibility for hospital and nursing home care for Persian Gulf War veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards, despite lack of medical evidence linking disability to exposure. Outpatient care provisions are also specified. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may provide medical services to veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during service, even without conclusive medical evidence linking disability to the exposure. Reimbursement is available for veterans who paid for care related to such exposure. Effective date for these amendments is August 2, 1990. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can offer medical services to veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during service, even without definitive medical evidence linking disability to the exposure. Reimbursement is available for veterans who paid for care related to such exposure, with the amendments taking effect on August 2, 1990. The extension of certain health care and other authorities for veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War includes reimbursement for care paid by veterans, eligibility for care for exposure to dioxin or ionizing radiation extended to June 30, 1994, and eligibility for sexual trauma counseling extended to December 31, 1994. The eligibility for sexual trauma counseling is extended to December 31, 1994, along with other health care authorities for veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War. Additionally, certain deadlines for maintaining regional offices and advisory committees are also extended to December 31, 1994. SEC. 3. SHARING OF RESOURCES WITH STATE HOMES. The purpose of amending section 8151 of title 38, United States Code, is to improve care for veterans by allowing the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources. The definition of "health-care resource" is expanded to include various services and support. Sharing of health-care resources under section 8153(a) is also amended. The amendment allows the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources, including specialized medical resources and other health-care resources. The Secretary can enter agreements with State veterans facilities to share specialized medical and health-care resources, including those with organ banks, blood banks, research centers, and medical schools. The agreements must either eliminate the need for duplicate resources in Department health care facilities or ensure that Department resources allocated for veterans' care are used effectively.
